notes.note_text:
Session 1

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported that child is “hard to understand” for unfamiliar listeners and often leaves off sounds at the ends of words. No prior speech therapy. Parent notices that /k/ and /g/ are usually replaced with /t/ and /d/ (e.g., “tat” for “cat”).
- No major changes in speech over the past few months per parent; family is motivated to start home practice.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- 4-year-old child transitioned to the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from parent with reassurance.
- Once settled, child engaged well in play-based activities and followed simple directions. Attention was best with hands-on toys and picture books. Occasional silliness when tasks became more challenging, but generally redirectable.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Establish /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Baseline probing showed consistent fronting of /k/ to /t/ in all positions.
- With direct modeling and visual cues (showing “back tongue” in mirror), child was able to approximate /k/ in isolation in a few trials; productions were often “t-k” or very light contact.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “koo, kah”), accuracy was low; child reverted to /t/ most of the time. Required maximal verbal and visual cueing.

Goal 2: Establish /g/ in isolation
- Similar pattern of fronting /g/ to /d/. In isolation, child produced a few close approximations of /g/ with simultaneous modeling.
- Needed repeated reminders to “lift tongue at the back” and to keep lips relaxed. Accuracy remained inconsistent.

Goal 3: Initial /k/ at imitated word level (emerging)
- Probed initial /k/ in simple words (e.g., “key, cow, car, cookie”). Child mostly produced /t/ (e.g., “tee” for “key”).
- With maximal modeling, segmentation (“k—ey”), and tactile cue under chin, child produced a few clearer /k/ sounds, but not yet consistent.

Goal 4: Final consonant production (p, m, t) in CVC words
- Screening during play showed frequent omission of final consonants (e.g., “bee” for “beep,” “boo” for “boom”).
- With model and visual cue (pointing to mouth for “end sound”), child could sometimes add a final /p/ or /m/, but needed frequent repetition and support.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to focus on establishing /k/ and /g/ in isolation and simple syllables before moving more fully to word level.
- Introduce simple final consonant practice with high-interest words.
- Home practice: parent to model “back sounds” /k, g/ in a mirror for short, playful practice (1–2 minutes), emphasizing listening and watching rather than pushing for perfection.
- Next session: recheck /k/ and /g/ in isolation and CV syllables; continue to probe final consonants in CVC words.

Session 2

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported child has been “showing off” new sounds at home but they still mostly hear /t/ for /k/ and /d/ for /g/ in words.
- Parent attempted mirror practice a few times; child was cooperative for short periods.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned smoothly today and appeared excited to come into the room.
- Good participation in structured play; attended well to picture cards and mirror work for short bursts. Needed occasional breaks with toys between drill tasks.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Marked breakthrough compared to last week. With verbal cue (“tongue in the back”) and mirror, child produced a clear /k/ in isolation in most attempts.
- In CV combinations (e.g., “koo, kah, kee”), accuracy improved notably. Child was able to maintain the back tongue position with moderate verbal cueing and occasional visual reminder.

Goal 2: /g/ in isolation and CV syllables
- /g/ also more accurate today. Child produced several good /g/ sounds in isolation with model.
- In CV syllables (“goo, gah, gee”), productions were mixed; some reverted to /d/, but there were more successful trials than last session.

Goal 3: Initial /k/ at imitated word level
- Practiced simple words (key, cow, car, cookie, cat). Child more consistently initiated words with a recognizable /k/ when given a slow model and cue to “start with the back sound.”
- Still needed moderate support, but accuracy was noticeably better than baseline.

Goal 4: Final /p, m/ in CVC words (imitated)
- Targeted final consonants in high-interest words (pop, beep, boom, mom).
- With modeling and a visual cue (touching chin for end sound), child was able to add final /p/ and /m/ more often than last session, though omissions still occurred.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue strengthening /k/ and /g/ in CV syllables and initial word position, aiming for more automatic productions.
- Maintain short, fun final consonant practice.
- Home practice: parent to use a few target words (e.g., key, cow, pop, mom) and emphasize the “back sound” and the “end sound,” praising any attempts.
- Next session: consider expanding initial /k/ to a small set of words in simple carrier phrases if accuracy remains strong.

Session 3

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent noted child has started to say “car” and “cookie” with a clearer /k/ at times, especially right after they practice together.
- Still many instances of /t/ for /k/ in everyday speech. Parent feels they are noticing the errors more now.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child separated easily from parent and was eager to choose toys.
- Maintained attention well with turn-taking games. Some playful avoidance (e.g., silly answers) when tasks became more repetitive, but responded to choices and praise.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: /k/ in CV and VC syllables
- Child produced /k/ in CV syllables with good consistency when given a model and brief reminder. Accuracy has increased since last week, requiring slightly fewer cues.
- Introduced VC syllables (e.g., “ak, ick, ook”); child was able to mark the final /k/ in some attempts but often omitted or fronted it.

Goal 2: Initial /k/ at word level (imitation and early spontaneous attempts)
- Practiced initial /k/ words (key, cow, car, cookie, cat, coat) in picture naming.
- In imitation, productions were more consistent, with clearer back tongue placement; fewer /t/ substitutions.
- Child occasionally used /k/ spontaneously during play (e.g., “car go”), though not yet reliable.

Goal 3: Initial /g/ in isolation and CV
- /g/ remains more challenging than /k/ but showed some improvement.
- In isolation, child could produce /g/ with model and visual cue; still occasional /d/ substitutions.
- In CV syllables (goo, gah, gee), child had emerging accuracy with frequent reminders.

Goal 4: Final /p, m, t/ in CVC words
- Continued work on final consonants (pop, beep, boom, bat, bed, mom).
- With modeling and gesture cues, child more frequently included the final sound, though not yet consistent.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen /k/ in CV/VC and initial word positions; begin to incorporate simple carrier phrases with support if accuracy holds (e.g., “my car,” “big cookie”).
- Maintain practice with /g/ and final consonants at the word level with cues.
- Home practice: encourage short practice of a few /k/ words in a simple phrase (e.g., “my car”), accepting approximations and praising effort.
- Next session: monitor readiness to increase phrase-level practice for /k/ in structured tasks.

Session 4

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported hearing more “good /k/ sounds” in play, especially for “car” and “cookie.” They notice child sometimes corrects themselves after hearing the parent’s model.
- Parent feels child enjoys the practice games and asks to “play sounds” occasionally.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned quickly, brought a toy car to show the clinician.
- Very engaged in play-based activities; tolerated short periods of structured drill when interspersed with games.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ at word and simple phrase level
- At the imitated word level, child showed increased consistency for target words (car, cow, cat, cookie, key, coat). Needed fewer prompts to use the back tongue.
- Introduced simple carrier phrases (e.g., “my car,” “big cookie,” “red coat”) with visual supports. Child was able to produce several phrases with reasonably clear /k/ in initial position, especially when given a slow model.

Goal 2: /k/ in VC and CVC syllable shapes
- Practiced VC syllables (ak, ick, oak, ook) and simple CVC words (back, book, bike).
- Child more frequently marked the final /k/ with verbal and gestural cueing, though omissions still occurred.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued to target /g/ in isolation and simple CV (goo, gah, go).
- Child showed slightly better accuracy and was able to hold the back tongue position with moderate cueing, but /g/ remains less stable than /k/.

Goal 4: Final /p, t/ in CVC words
- Focused on a small set of high-interest CVC words (pop, up, hat, cat, hot).
- With modeling and a visual cue for the “end sound,” child included final consonants more often than not in structured practice. Still tends to drop them in spontaneous speech.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to build phrase-level practice for initial /k/ in structured tasks while maintaining accuracy.
- Ongoing work on /g/ and final consonants, with emphasis on listening and self-awareness.
- Home practice: parent to use a few target phrases (e.g., “my car,” “big cookie”) during daily routines and reinforce any attempts at the back sound.
- Next session: consider expanding /k/ targets to include more varied vowels and positions as accuracy stabilizes.

Session 5

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported speech “sounds about the same” as last week. They still notice clearer /k/ in some practiced words, but everyday conversation is mixed.
- Home practice was less frequent this week due to family schedule.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child separated easily but appeared a bit tired. Needed more frequent movement breaks between tasks.
- Still participated in activities, though attention span for drill was slightly shorter than previous sessions.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ at word and phrase level
- At the imitated word level, accuracy for initial /k/ remained generally similar to last week. Child continued to produce /k/ correctly in familiar words with moderate cueing.
- In short carrier phrases (“my car,” “big cookie,” “go car”), child could produce several accurate phrases with support, but there was not a noticeable increase in independence.

Goal 2: /k/ in VC and CVC forms
- VC syllables (ak, ick, ook) and CVC words (back, book, bike) practiced again.
- Performance was stable; child marked the final /k/ in some trials but still omitted it frequently without direct prompting.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and CV
- Continued work on /g/ with mirror and verbal cues.
- Accuracy was comparable to last week. Child produced some good /g/ sounds in isolation but still defaulted to /d/ without strong support.

Goal 4: Final /p, t/ in CVC words
- Practiced pop, up, hat, hot, cat.
- Child’s production of final consonants appeared similar to previous session, with good success when closely supported and frequent omissions in less structured attempts.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Maintain current level of practice for /k/ and /g/ while consolidating skills; no major changes to hierarchy this week.
- Reinforce final consonant awareness through short, fun games (e.g., listening for “end sounds”).
- Home practice: encourage brief daily practice using picture cards or toys for 5 minutes, focusing on a small set of /k/ words and final consonant words.
- Next session: reassess readiness to increase independence at phrase level for /k/ and consider introducing new contexts if performance strengthens.

Session 6

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported a “few more clear words” this week, especially with /k/ in “car” and “cookie,” and felt child was trying harder to copy their models.
- Parent noted they were able to fit in short practice most days.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child came in with good energy and quickly engaged in the session routine.
- Participated well in structured activities and enjoyed choosing reward games after completing sets of practice trials.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ at word and phrase level (increasing independence)
- At the imitated word level, child produced initial /k/ with higher consistency across a wider set of words (car, cow, cat, cookie, key, coat, cup).
- In short carrier phrases (“my car,” “big cookie,” “red coat,” “go cat”), child required slightly fewer prompts and occasionally produced an accurate /k/ in phrases with only a light reminder.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words (initial and final)
- Practiced CVC words with /k/ in initial and/or final position (cake, back, book, bike).
- Child more frequently marked both the initial and final /k/ when provided with a model and a brief cue for the end sound. Omissions still occurred but there was an emerging pattern of improved consistency.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and initial word level (imitated)
- /g/ in isolation showed modest improvement; child could produce several good /g/ sounds with verbal cues.
- Introduced a few initial /g/ words in imitation (go, gum, game). Accuracy was variable but there were some successful productions with clear back tongue placement.

Goal 4: Final /p, t/ in CVC words
- Continued work on final /p/ and /t/ in words like pop, up, hat, hot, cat.
- Child demonstrated slightly more frequent inclusion of final consonants during structured drill, particularly when the clinician highlighted the difference between words with and without end sounds.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to increase independence for initial /k/ at word and phrase level, gradually reducing cues where possible.
- Keep practicing /g/ in isolation and a few simple words, watching for readiness to expand.
- Maintain final consonant work with engaging games.
- Home practice: parent to practice a small list of /k/ words and phrases, emphasizing child’s attempts and gently prompting for the back sound when needed.
- Next session: trial some simple play-based opportunities for more spontaneous /k/ productions during structured play scenes (e.g., cars, cooking).

Session 7

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported that overall speech feels “pretty similar” to last week. They still hear better /k/ in practice words but mixed accuracy in conversation.
- Home practice occurred several days, though some sessions were shorter.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned easily but was somewhat distracted at the start of the session, wanting to explore toys.
- With structured choices and clear expectations, child participated adequately in practice tasks.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ at word and phrase level
- Child continued to produce initial /k/ reliably in familiar words when given a model or brief cue.
- In carrier phrases (“my car,” “big cookie,” “go cat”), performance was comparable to last session. Child could produce several accurate phrases but still relied on prompts; no marked change in independence.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words (initial and final)
- Practiced CVC words such as cake, back, book, bike.
- Child showed similar accuracy to last week, marking initial /k/ more consistently than final /k/. Final /k/ still required explicit cueing.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and simple words
- /g/ practice in isolation and in words (go, gum, game) yielded variable results, similar to previous session.
- Child occasionally produced a good /g/ but reverted to /d/ without strong cues.

Goal 4: Final /p, t/ in CVC words
- Continued practice with pop, up, hat, hot, cat.
- Inclusion of final consonants remained stable; child did well with close modeling but did not yet generalize to less structured play.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Maintain focus on consolidating /k/ at word and phrase level and continue to support final consonant production.
- Keep /g/ practice brief but consistent, emphasizing listening to the difference between /g/ and /d/.
- Home practice: encourage parent to use short, predictable phrases with /k/ words during daily routines (e.g., “my cup,” “big car”), praising effort.
- Next session: re-evaluate whether to introduce more play-based opportunities for spontaneous /k/ or to continue at current level depending on performance.

Session 8

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported noticing more clear /k/ sounds in everyday play, especially when child is talking about cars or cookies without being directly prompted.
- Parent feels child is starting to correct themselves occasionally after hearing the parent’s model.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child came in cheerful and quickly engaged with car-themed activities.
- Sustained attention well during both drill and play-based tasks, responding positively to specific praise for “back sounds” and “end sounds.”

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ at word, phrase, and early spontaneous levels
- In structured picture naming, child produced initial /k/ in a broad set of words with strong consistency and only light cueing.
- During simple play scenarios (car garage, kitchen play), child spontaneously used several words with initial /k/ (car, cookie, cup, key) with clearer back sounds than in previous sessions.
- Short carrier phrases (“my car,” “more cookies,” “big cup”) were produced with increasing independence once the phrase was established.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words and phrases
- Practiced CVC words (cake, back, book, bike, coke) and incorporated them into short phrases (e.g., “big cake,” “my book”).
- Child more consistently marked both initial and final /k/ when given a model and brief visual cue for end sounds. Accuracy was noticeably higher than in earlier sessions.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and initial word level
- /g/ in isolation showed further improvement; child produced more reliable /g/ sounds with moderate verbal cues.
- In initial /g/ words (go, gum, game, gate), child achieved several clear productions in imitation and occasionally in short phrases (e.g., “go car,” “go game”), though /d/ substitutions still occurred.

Goal 4: Final consonants /p, t, k/ in CVC words
- Targeted a mix of final consonants in high-interest words (pop, up, hat, hot, back, book).
- Child demonstrated improved awareness of end sounds, sometimes self-correcting after the clinician modeled the contrast. Accuracy during structured tasks was higher, with reduced need for maximal cueing.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to expand opportunities for spontaneous /k/ in play and short conversational exchanges.
- Gradually increase phrase-level work for /g/ as accuracy allows.
- Maintain practice with final consonants and begin to link them more to functional words and phrases.
- Home practice: parent to highlight and praise spontaneous /k/ and /g/ productions, and to play simple games (e.g., “I spy my car/cup/cake”) using target words.
- Next session: continue to support generalization of /k/ to more spontaneous speech and monitor /g/ progress.

Session 9

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported that speech this week felt similar to last week, with lots of good /k/ words in play but still some “baby sounds” when child is excited or talking fast.
- Parent is noticing /g/ is still harder and tends to sound like /d/ most of the time.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned well but was quite energetic. Needed a brief movement break early in the session.
- Once settled, child participated adequately in both structured and play-based tasks.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ in words, phrases, and play
- Performance at the word and simple phrase level remained strong and similar to last session. Child produced initial /k/ accurately in most familiar words with minimal cueing.
- During play, child used several /k/ words spontaneously (car, cookie, key, cup), with occasional reversion to /t/ when speaking quickly. No major change from prior session but maintained gains.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words and short phrases
- Continued work on CVC words (cake, back, book, bike) and phrases (big cake, my book).
- Accuracy was comparable to last week. Child generally marked both initial and final /k/ in structured practice but still needed reminders in spontaneous utterances.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and initial words
- /g/ practice remained challenging, with accuracy similar to previous session. Child could produce /g/ in isolation with modeling but defaulted to /d/ frequently in words (go, game, gate).
- Some emerging correct productions in imitation, but not yet consistent enough to move up levels.

Goal 4: Final consonants /p, t, k/ in CVC words
- Practiced a mix of final consonants in structured drill and simple games.
- Child maintained prior gains, showing good inclusion of final consonants with clear cues. No significant shift in independence yet.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue consolidating skills for /k/ across word and phrase levels and reinforce carryover into natural play.
- Maintain focused practice on /g/ in isolation and a small set of words, aiming for more consistent contrast with /d/.
- Ongoing final consonant work, gradually embedding targets into simple functional phrases.
- Home practice: encourage parent to draw attention to “back sounds” during shared book reading or play, and to model slow, clear productions for /k/ and /g/ words.
- Next session: reassess /g/ accuracy and consider whether to adjust cueing strategies or target selection.

Session 10

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported no major changes from last week. Child continues to use clear /k/ in many practiced words but still mixes in /t/ in fast or excited speech.
- Parent feels /g/ is “slowly improving” but remains inconsistent.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child separated easily and followed the routine.
- Engagement was generally good, though child requested more frequent changes in activities; responded well to short, varied tasks.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ at word and phrase level, and spontaneous use
- At the word and phrase level, child maintained good accuracy for initial /k/ with light cues.
- In play, child produced several /k/ words spontaneously. Accuracy appeared stable relative to previous session, with similar patterns of occasional fronting when excited.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words and short phrases
- Practiced CVC targets (cake, back, book, bike) in drill and simple phrases (big cake, my book, red bike).
- Performance remained comparable to last week; child generally marked both initial and final /k/ in structured tasks, with some omissions when cues were faded.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and initial words
- Continued to work on /g/ using mirror and auditory contrast with /d/.
- Child produced some good /g/ sounds in isolation and a few clearer productions in words such as go and game when given strong cues. Overall accuracy was similar to prior session.

Goal 4: Final consonants /p, t, k/ in CVC words
- Targeted final consonants through a board game format.
- Child included final sounds consistently with direct modeling and reminders but still omitted them when attention shifted to the game itself.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Maintain focus on consolidating /k/ across contexts while continuing to support gradual improvement for /g/.
- Continue to practice final consonants in fun, structured activities, with slow fading of cues as tolerated.
- Home practice: parent to continue short daily practice with picture cards or toys for both /k/ and /g/, and to play listening games to notice “end sounds.”
- Next session: review overall progress this block and discuss with parent potential next steps for goals.

Session 11

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported speech feels about the same as last week. They continue to hear many correct /k/ words and a few more attempts at /g/ but still lots of /d/ substitutions.
- Parent wonders how long it might take before others understand child more easily.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned well and followed directions without difficulty.
- Participated in structured tasks and play, though needed occasional reminders to stay seated during drill activities.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ in words, phrases, and conversation
- Child continued to produce initial /k/ accurately in familiar words and short phrases with minimal cueing.
- During play-based conversation, child used multiple /k/ words; accuracy patterns were stable, with strong performance when calm and more fronting when speaking quickly or excitedly.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words and short phrases
- Revisited CVC words (cake, back, book, bike) and associated phrases.
- Accuracy for both initial and final /k/ remained similar to prior sessions; child responded to cues but did not show a notable jump in independence.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and initial word level
- Practiced /g/ in isolation and in simple words (go, gum, game, gate).
- Child produced several correct /g/ sounds in isolation, but carryover into words was still inconsistent. Overall, performance paralleled previous weeks.

Goal 4: Final consonants /p, t, k/ in CVC words
- Final consonant targets were incorporated into a matching game.
- Child maintained prior skill level, producing end sounds well when closely supported and omitting them more when attention shifted.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue with current hierarchy for /k/ and /g/, emphasizing stability and gradual generalization to conversation.
- Maintain final consonant work, with an eye toward functional words that matter at home and school.
- Home practice: parent to focus on a few key phrases containing /k/ (e.g., “my cup,” “big cake”) and to continue modeling /g/ words slowly and clearly.
- Next session: wrap up this therapy block, summarize progress for parent, and discuss recommendations for ongoing therapy.

Session 12

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Parent reported no significant changes from last week. They continue to hear strong /k/ in practiced words and are noticing slow, gradual change for /g/.
- Parent expressed interest in continuing therapy to further improve clarity for unfamiliar listeners.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned easily and seemed comfortable with the therapy routine.
- Demonstrated good participation in both drill and play activities, with occasional need for redirection when excited.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Initial /k/ across word, phrase, and conversational levels
- At the structured word and phrase level, child continued to produce initial /k/ with high accuracy and minimal cueing, similar to previous sessions.
- In semi-structured conversation during play, child used many /k/ words; accuracy remained stable, with good productions when focused and occasional fronting when speech was rapid.

Goal 2: /k/ in CVC words and short phrases
- Practiced CVC words (cake, back, book, bike) and short phrases (big cake, my book, red bike) in a review format.
- Performance remained consistent with prior sessions. Child responded well to light reminders for end sounds but did not yet fully generalize this skill without support.

Goal 3: /g/ in isolation and initial words
- Continued work on /g/ in isolation and in a small set of initial /g/ words (go, game, gum, gate).
- Child produced several accurate /g/ sounds with modeling and visual cues. Word-level accuracy showed gradual but modest improvement; /d/ substitutions persisted but were less frequent in closely supported practice.

Goal 4: Final consonants /p, t, k/ in CVC words
- Final consonants were targeted in a review game using mixed CVC words.
- Child maintained ability to include final consonants with explicit cues, though independent use in more natural speech remains emerging.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Summarized progress with parent: child has made meaningful gains with /k/ across levels and is beginning to show more reliable /g/ and final consonant use in structured tasks.
- Recommend continued speech therapy to further support generalization of /k/ to spontaneous conversation, improve /g/ accuracy at the word and phrase levels, and strengthen final consonant production.
- Home practice: continue short daily practice with /k/ and /g/ words and phrases; encourage parent to model and gently prompt for back sounds and end sounds in everyday routines.
- Next steps: plan for ongoing weekly sessions with updated goals that build on current progress.

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother reported that child is “starting to say more sounds” but is still hard to understand for unfamiliar listeners.
- No recent changes in hearing or health. Family practicing some target words from previous block (e.g., “sun,” “sock”) informally.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned to therapy room with brief hesitation but joined session with encouragement.
- Engaged well in floor play and turn-taking games; occasional distraction by toys but redirected with visual supports and clear expectations.
- Responded best to short, play-based tasks with frequent movement breaks.

Goals/Activities:
1. Initial /s/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Practiced /s/ in isolation using visual cue for “snake sound.” Child approximated /s/ with intermittent lateral airflow; about half of attempts were clearly /s/.
- At CV syllable level (e.g., “see,” “sue,” “sah”), child required simultaneous production with SLP and moderate verbal and gestural cueing.
- At simple word level (e.g., “sun,” “sock,” “soap”), productions were inconsistent; frequent substitutions with /d/ (“dun” for “sun”).

2. Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Introduced “lip-bite” cue and mirror for /f/ sound. Child was able to imitate /f/ in isolation in several trials with visual model, though often added a vowel (“fuh”).
- In CV syllables (e.g., “fee,” “foo”), accuracy decreased; child sometimes produced /p/ or omitted the fricative portion.

3. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m/)
- Targeted final /p/ and /m/ in simple words (e.g., “cup,” “up,” “mom,” “ham”) at the imitated word level.
- Child frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous speech; with direct imitation and tactile cue (light tap on table for “ending sound”), produced clearer final consonants in several attempts but not consistently.

4. Two-word combinations with clear target words
- During structured play, encouraged short phrases such as “my sun,” “big sock,” and “more soap.”
- Child primarily produced single-word approximations; needed direct models and imitation to include both words.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue to establish consistent production of /s/ and /f/ in isolation and simple syllables before moving up the hierarchy.
- Encourage parents to practice “snake sound /s/” and “lip-bite /f/” in front of a mirror for short periods, keeping practice playful and brief.
- Next session: revisit initial /s/ and /f/ in isolation and syllables; continue to monitor final consonant use in play-based tasks.

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother shared that child is “copying” some of the practice sounds at home, especially the snake sound, but they are unsure if they are doing the cues correctly.
- No new concerns regarding hearing or general development.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child entered therapy room more easily today and appeared eager to explore toys.
- Maintained attention well during short, game-like tasks; occasional silliness when tasks became more challenging, but responded to gentle redirection.

Goals/Activities:
1. Initial /s/ in isolation, syllables, and simple words (imitation)
- Child produced /s/ in isolation with improved consistency when given the visual “snake” cue and reminder to keep tongue behind teeth; majority of attempts were clearly /s/.
- At CV level (e.g., “see,” “sah,” “soo”), accuracy increased compared to last session; able to imitate most targets with only brief verbal prompts.
- At word level (e.g., “sun,” “sock,” “soap,” “sit”), child demonstrated more consistent productions in imitation, with fewer substitutions to /d/.

2. Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables (imitation)
- Continued to use mirror and “lip-bite” explanation. Child showed better control of airflow and lip placement.
- In isolation, /f/ was clear in many attempts, with reduced tendency to add an extra vowel.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “fee,” “foe”), accuracy improved; fewer substitutions to /p/ were noted.

3. Final consonant production in CVC words (/p, m/)
- Practiced final /p/ and /m/ in words such as “cup,” “up,” “ham,” and “mom” with visual cueing (e.g., pointing to a picture of the “end sound”).

Session 1

Parent/caregiver report:
- Parent shared that they are most concerned about others not understanding child's speech, especially with new adults.
- Reported that child is starting preschool in the fall and they would like support with clearer words for basic needs (e.g., snack, bathroom, play).
- Parent noted that child often leaves off the ends of words and "mushes" longer words together.

Behavior/engagement:
- Child transitioned into the therapy room with some initial hesitation but joined play with encouragement.
- Engaged best with pretend play (farm, cars) and short, game-like tasks; needed occasional redirection away from self-directed play.
- Able to participate in structured practice for short bursts (3–5 trials) before needing a break.

Goals/targets this session:
1) Baseline for overall speech sound production
- Informal probe during play and picture naming.
- Noted frequent final consonant deletion (e.g., "pi" for "pig," "ca" for "cat").
- Reduced accuracy for /k/ and /g/ in initial position (e.g., "tat" for "cat," "do" for "go").
- Some difficulty with /s/ in initial position and /s/ blends (e.g., "top" for "stop," "pider" for "spider").

2) Final consonants (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted simple CVC words in imitation during picture naming and car-race game (e.g., "map," "cup," "hat," "ham").
- Child was able to imitate final /p/ and /m/ with moderate verbal and visual cues ("keep your lips together at the end"), but often omitted the final sound without cues.
- Final /t/ was more challenging; productions were often reduced ("ha" for "hat").

3) Initial /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Practiced "back sound" /k/ in isolation using visual cue (mirror) and verbal cueing ("tongue up and back").
- Child could approximate /k/ in isolation inconsistently with maximal support; often substituted /t/.
- In CV syllables ("ku," "ki"), accuracy was low; child showed some awareness and attempted to copy clinician’s mouth movements.

4) Initial /s/ in isolation
- Briefly introduced /s/ as a "long, quiet snake sound."
- Child produced a prolonged /s/ in isolation in a few attempts with modeling, though with occasional stopping or added vowel ("suh").

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to establish consistent final consonants in simple CVC words and build reliable /k/ in isolation and CV syllables.
- Provide parent with simple home practice list for CVC words with final /p/ and /m/ (e.g., map, mop, cup, gum) using a "tap the last sound" strategy.
- Next session: Re-check baseline for /k/ and final consonants, and consider introducing a small set of functional words (e.g., "cup," "up," "cat").

Goals/targets this session:
1) Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Practiced final /p/ and /m/ in imitation during picture naming and a fishing game (e.g., "map," "mop," "cup," "ham").
- With moderate verbal and visual cues (emphasizing the last sound), child produced final /p/ and /m/ more consistently than last session; still tended to drop endings in spontaneous attempts.
- Final /t/ remained inconsistent; often reduced to an open syllable ("ha" for "hat"). Some emerging attempts to add a "t" with heavy modeling.

2) Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued focus on "back sound" /k/ in front of the mirror.
- Child produced /k/ in isolation more reliably with maximal cueing (tongue back cue, clinician modeling); still frequent /t/ substitutions.
- In CV syllables ("ku," "ka," "ki"), child imitated /k/ accurately in a small number of trials when paced slowly; accuracy decreased as speed increased.

- Introduced a small set of initial /k/ words in imitation ("car," "cow," "key").

- Revisited /s/ as a "long snake sound" in isolation.
- Child produced /s/ independently in isolation a few times after a model; still added a vowel in many attempts ("suh").
- Briefly trialed CV syllables ("see," "soo"), with emerging accuracy when given a slow model.

Plan/recommendations:
- Skills appear similar to baseline overall, with some early signs of increased attempts at endings and /k/.
- Continue focusing on final consonants in functional CVC words and building more consistent /k/ and /s/ in isolation and syllables.
- Home practice: Encourage short, play-based practice of CVC words (e.g., during snack with "cup," "up," "ham") and model clear final sounds without pressuring child to repeat every time.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, t, m/)

- Practiced initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables (“ku, ko, kee”), then moved into a small set of words (e.g., “car, key”).

- Observed spontaneous 2–3 word phrases in play (e.g., “my car,” “more bubbles,” “I want that”).
- Speech intelligibility decreased in longer phrases due to sound errors and reduced final consonants.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue targeting final consonant production and initial /k/ and /s/ at the imitated word level next session.

Parent report:
- Caregiver shared that they are most concerned about child's speech clarity, especially with new listeners. Noted that child often leaves off sounds at the ends of words and sometimes "mushes" words together. No major changes since initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned with some hesitation but separated from caregiver with reassurance. Once in the room, child was curious and engaged with toys. Attention to adult-directed tasks was variable; needed frequent reminders to "listen" and return to table tasks but responded well to short, play-based activities.

Goals / Observations:
1. Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Targeted early consonants /m, b, p/ in simple syllables (e.g., "ma," "bee," "boo," "mama," "baby"). Child imitated CV shapes fairly consistently, though productions were sometimes quiet or slightly distorted. CVCV forms were more effortful; child tended to reduce to one syllable (e.g., "mama" → "ma"). Moderate verbal models and visual cues were needed.

2. Final consonant production (CVC words)
- Introduced final /p, t, m/ at imitated word level (e.g., "cup," "cat," "ham"). Child frequently omitted final sounds or added a schwa ("cup" → "cuh"). With direct modeling and visual cues (tapping for end sound), child produced a few clearer final consonants, but accuracy remained low and inconsistent.

3. Initial /k/ in isolation and syllables
- Practiced back-of-the-tongue sound /k/ in isolation using mirror and tongue-back cues. Child could approximate /k/ in isolation intermittently but often substituted /t/. In CV syllables ("koo," "kee"), substitutions persisted. Tactile and verbal prompts were required for most trials.

4. Early phrase production for clarity (2–3 word combinations)
- In play, child used many 2–3 word phrases, but several words within the phrase were not clearly articulated. SLP modeled slower, slightly exaggerated productions (e.g., "big ball," "my car"). Child occasionally imitated clearer versions with direct imitation but did not yet carry this over independently.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue focusing on establishing consistent final consonants and more accurate /k/ in isolation and simple syllables. Maintain practice of CV and CVCV syllable shapes with early consonants.
- Caregiver encouraged to model slow, clear speech at home and emphasize end sounds in a natural way (e.g., gently highlighting the last sound in words like "cup" and "hat").
- Plan to reassess response to /k/ cues next session and consider introducing a small set of familiar CVC words if accuracy in isolation improves.

- Practiced /k/ in isolation, then in CV syllables. Child produced a clearer /k/ sound in isolation several times with tongue-back cues and mirror. In syllables ("koo," "key"), still often substituted /t/, but there were a few accurate productions with immediate imitation.

Goals and observations:
1. Initial /k/ at syllable and word level
- Baseline probing completed. In isolation, he could approximate /k/ in 4/10 attempts with maximal verbal and visual cues ("tongue in the back" and mirror). In simple CV syllables ("ku, ki, ko"), accuracy decreased (2–3/10), with frequent fronting to /t/ (e.g., "too" for "coo"). At the word level ("car, key, cow"), he produced mostly /t/ substitutions in imitation. Requires direct modeling plus tactile cue on throat.

2. Final consonant production (p, t, m) in CVC words
- Probed final consonant production in imitation using picture cards ("cup, cat, home, map, boat"). Frequently omitted final consonants, producing open syllables ("cu" for "cup," "ca" for "cat"). With simultaneous production and exaggerated clinician model, he marked the final sound in ~2/10 trials across sounds. Greater success with final /m/ in "home" and "ham" when whispered first.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Attempted /s/ in isolation with visual cue (smile, teeth together, long airflow). He produced a mix of /d/ and /th/ substitutions, with occasional brief /s/-like frication when directly shaping from a long /t/ ("tssss"). Able to sustain an approximated /s/ in isolation in 3/10 attempts with maximal verbal and gestural cues. Not yet consistent in CV syllables.

4. Functional communication / spontaneous language sample
- During play, produced mainly 2–3-word phrases ("my car," "I want that," "no mine"). Intelligibility reduced at the sentence level due to sound errors and omissions. Able to repair breakdowns occasionally when prompted ("tell me again").

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to establish accurate /k/ in isolation and simple syllables before expanding to more word practice.
- Continue targeting final consonants (p, t, m) in high-interest words using simultaneous production and tactile cues.
- Introduce parent to "whisper the last sound" strategy for final consonants during book reading.
- Provide caregiver with a short list of practice words for /k/ and final /m/ at the imitation level.

Goals and observations:
1. Initial /k/ in conversation and narratives
- Maintained high accuracy with /k/ in conversation and simple narratives about his week. Very few instances of fronting were noted, primarily in longer or unfamiliar words. He required only occasional prompts and demonstrated consistent generalization in a variety of contexts.

2. Final consonant production (p, t, m) in CVC words and short phrases
- Accuracy levels were similar to prior sessions: final /m/ ~8/10, final /p/ ~7/10, final /t/ ~5/10 in imitation with cues. In phrases, he continued to mark final /m/ and /p/ in about half of attempts and often omitted final /t/. He benefited from slowed rate and segmentation but did not yet carry this over independently.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- /s/ performance remained stable. Isolation accuracy around 8/10 with minimal cueing; syllable-level around 6/10 with some persistent distortions. He continued to enjoy "snake sound" activities but required similar levels of support as previous weeks.

4. Functional communication
- Used multi-word sentences and basic story-telling about preschool. Intelligibility improved for topics with familiar vocabulary but remained reduced overall due to ongoing phonological patterns.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to monitor /k/ in conversation but shift primary treatment focus toward final consonants and /s/ as /k/ is nearing generalization.
- Maintain targeted practice for final /p, t, m" and consider adding simple visual cues for final /t/ (e.g., drawing a dot for the last sound).
- Continue /s/ syllable practice; re-assess readiness for word-level targets in upcoming sessions.
- Encourage caregiver to focus on a few "power words" at home for final consonants and to keep practices positive and brief.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that family continues to notice clearer "car" and "cookie" productions. She has been working on words like "cat" and "cup" at home and feels he can do them when they practice slowly, but he "forgets" in regular talking.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Entered willingly and checked in with the clinician verbally. Participated well in both table-top and play-based tasks. Needed occasional prompts to stay seated during structured activities.

Goals and observations:
1. Initial /k/ in conversation
- /k/ remained consistently accurate in conversation across familiar topics. Only rare fronting errors occurred, and he typically accepted prompts to repeat. This skill appears stable at the conversational level.

2. Final consonant production (p, t, m) in CVC words and short phrases
- Accuracy remained similar to last several sessions. In imitation, final /m/ ~8/10, final /p/ ~7/10, final /t/ ~5/10 with visual and tactile cues. In short phrases, he continued to mark final /m/ and /p/ in roughly half of attempts and tended to omit final /t/. No notable change in independence or generalization.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- /s/ production continued at a similar level: isolation ~8/10, CV syllables ~6/10 with mild distortions. He was able to adjust slightly with reminders to keep his tongue behind his teeth but still needed consistent cueing.

4. Functional communication
- Used complex sentences and expanded comments during play. Intelligibility to the clinician was fair to good in context; unfamiliar listeners would likely still need repetition and context support.

Plan/recommendations:
- Maintain monitoring of /k/ while focusing direct treatment time on final consonants and /s/.
- Continue practice with a limited set of high-value final /p, t, m" words and phrases, emphasizing slow rate and tapping cues.
- Continue /s/ syllable work; consider trialing a small number of simple /s/ words in imitation to probe readiness, while recognizing that syllable-level stability is still developing.
- Encourage caregiver to keep home practice short and consistent, praising effort and approximations rather than only perfect productions.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that he remains enthusiastic about "practicing his sounds" and will occasionally remind her, "I did my back sound!" She continues to notice missing final sounds in many words but is pleased with his increased talking and confidence.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Transitioned easily and was eager to begin. Stayed engaged throughout the session with minimal redirection. Responded well to visual supports and positive feedback.

Goals and observations:
1. Initial /k/ in conversation
- /k/ productions remained consistently accurate in conversational speech across a variety of topics and activities. Rare errors were observed and were easily corrected when prompted. This target appears well-established at this level.

2. Final consonant production (p, t, m) in CVC words and short phrases
- Performance remained in the same range as recent sessions. In imitation, final /m/ ~8/10, final /p/ ~7/10, final /t/ ~5/10 with cues. In short phrases, he continued to show better maintenance of final /m/ and /p" than /t" and still relied on clinician support to slow down and mark the last sound. No clear shift in independence yet.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables; probe for word level
- Isolation and CV syllable accuracy remained stable (isolation ~8/10, syllables ~6/10). Briefly probed simple /s/ words in imitation (e.g., "sun," "sock"). He produced approximations with mixed accuracy and required substantial cueing; not yet ready for consistent word-level practice.

4. Functional communication
- Continued to use multi-word sentences to share stories and participate in play. Intelligibility was improved for familiar topics but still reduced overall due to ongoing final consonant and /s/ difficulties.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to monitor /k/ in conversation but shift primary treatment focus toward improving final consonant accuracy and advancing /s/ when ready.
- Maintain intensive practice on a small, functional set of final /p, t, m" words and phrases, gradually encouraging more independent productions.
- Continue shaping /s/ in syllables and revisit word-level practice as accuracy and consistency improve.
- Caregiver to continue short daily practice with chosen target words, emphasizing slow, clear speech and specific praise for marked final sounds and successful "snake sounds."

Parent report:
Mother reported that she is understanding most of his speech at home, but other family members still ask for repetition. She noted he often leaves off the last sound in words (e.g., “ca” for “cat”) and sometimes says “tup” for “cup.” No major changes since the initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned into the therapy room with minimal hesitation, holding mom’s hand. He engaged well with toys and responded positively to praise and visual supports. Attention was best in short, play-based activities (3–4 minutes) with frequent changes in materials.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonant production (p, t, k) in CVC words – imitation level
- Targeted words such as “cup, cap, cat, hat, hot, hop, back, bike.”
- With simultaneous production and maximal verbal/visual cueing (e.g., “say it with your quiet stop sound at the end”), client produced final consonants accurately in some trials but frequently omitted or neutralized them (e.g., “cu” for “cup”).
- Accuracy was inconsistent and strongly cue-dependent; he did not yet carry over to independent productions.

2. Initial /k/ in isolation and simple syllables (CV)
- Practiced “k” in isolation using “tongue back” cues and a mirror.
- Able to imitate /k/ in isolation intermittently but often substituted /t/ despite cues.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “koo, kah”), production was mostly fronted to /t/; successful productions occurred only with slow pacing and maximal verbal models.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation
- Introduced “long, quiet snake sound” /s/ in isolation.
- Client could approximate a prolonged /s/ with strong visual models; intermittent nasal emission and stopping observed.
- Not yet ready to move to syllables; focus remained on establishing a consistent airflow and tongue placement.

4. Functional phrases for requesting
- During play, modeled short, functional phrases (e.g., “more cars,” “my turn”).
- Client primarily used single words or gestures to request; imitated some two-word combinations with direct models.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to establish final consonants and initial /k/ and /s/ at the isolation and simple word level with heavy support.
- Encourage parents to model clear final sounds in daily routines (e.g., emphasizing end sounds in simple words like “up, out, in, hot”) without pressuring him to repeat.
- Next session: maintain current targets; consider adding simple minimal pairs (e.g., “key/tea”) if /k/ in isolation stabilizes.

Parent report:
Mother reported that she has been trying to slow down her speech and emphasize end sounds. She notices he occasionally says “up” more clearly now, but most of the time final sounds are still missing. No concerns with hearing or health this week.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client separated from mom with reassurance and joined the session willingly. He was playful and cooperative, though he needed frequent redirection from self-directed play back to speech tasks. Responded well to turn-taking games and visual token reinforcement.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonant production (p, t, k) in CVC words – imitation level
- Practiced “cup, cap, cat, coat, bike, back, eat, out.”
- Compared to last week, he produced more audible final /p/ and /t/ when given a clear model and verbal cue (e.g., “stop your sound at the end”).
- Still inconsistent, but showed a slight increase in attempts to add the end sound, even when not fully accurate.

2. Initial /k/ in CV and CVC words – imitation
- Continued with tongue-back cues and mirror.
- Client produced /k/ in isolation more consistently, though still not yet automatic.
- At the word level (e.g., “key, car, cat”), he continued to substitute /t/ frequently, but there were a few clear /k/ productions with maximal cueing. Emerging improvement noted, but still at the imitated word level.

3. Initial /s/ isolation and CV syllables
- Revisited /s/ as a “long, quiet snake sound.”
- Able to hold /s/ for several seconds with visual cue to keep tongue behind teeth.
- Introduced simple syllables (“see, soo”); accuracy was variable, with some productions distorted or stopped, but overall more consistent than at baseline.

4. Two-word functional phrases in play
- Modeled and elicited two-word requests (e.g., “more bubbles,” “big car”).
- Client imitated several two-word phrases and independently produced a few (e.g., “my car,” “more please”) with light cueing.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain focus on final consonants and initial /k/ and /s/ at the word and syllable levels, emphasizing accuracy with strong models.
- Encourage caregivers to continue modeling end sounds and to praise any attempts where he adds a final sound, even if not perfect.
- Next session: consider beginning simple minimal pairs for final consonants (e.g., “bee/beep”) to heighten his awareness if consistency continues to improve.

Parent report:
Mother shared that he is starting to copy her when she exaggerates end sounds, especially with “up” and “out.” She feels he is “trying harder” to fix his words when she repeats them. No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client entered the room independently and appeared eager to play. Attention was improved; he remained engaged in structured tasks for longer intervals when activities were presented as games. Accepted verbal feedback and enjoyed earning stickers.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, k) in CVC words – imitation and emerging spontaneous
- Practiced a variety of CVC words (e.g., “cup, cap, cat, coat, cut, bike, back, book”).
- Notable increase in accuracy with final /p/ and /t/ in imitation; fewer omissions compared to prior sessions.
- Began to produce some final consonants spontaneously in play (e.g., “up” and “out” during a ball game) after prior modeling, indicating early carryover.

2. Initial /k/ in CV and CVC words – word level, mostly imitation
- Targets included “key, car, cow, cat, cup, cookie.”
- Marked breakthrough in his ability to produce /k/ with reduced cueing; he often achieved a correct /k/ after only a verbal reminder (“tongue in the back”) rather than full visual/tactile support.
- Fewer substitutions to /t/ and more consistent accuracy across different words.

3. Initial /s/ in CV and CVC words – imitation level
- Practiced “see, sun, soup, sock, sit.”
- Client produced a clearer, sustained /s/ at the beginning of words with moderate cues.
- Accuracy was higher than last session, with fewer stops and distortions. Some spontaneous “sss” sounds during play when prompted to make the “snake sound.”

4. Two- and three-word phrases in structured play
- Encouraged short phrases in routines (e.g., “more blue bubbles,” “I want cars”).
- Client imitated 2–3 word phrases well and occasionally initiated his own short combinations with intelligible key words.

Plan / recommendations:
- Given the improvement, begin to probe final consonants and initial /k/ in short carrier phrases next session (e.g., “I see __,” “my __”).
- Continue to support /s/ at the word level; once more stable, will trial simple phrases.
- At home, encourage slow, clear models and praise for any attempts with clearer end sounds or back sounds (/k/).

Parent report:
Mother reported that his “k” sound is noticeably clearer this week in words like “car” and “cookie.” She still notices missing end sounds in longer words but feels familiar listeners are understanding him better.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client transitioned smoothly and quickly chose a preferred toy. He was very engaged and talkative, often commenting on the activities. Required occasional reminders to wait for his turn to speak but remained cooperative and motivated.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, k) in CVC words and short phrases
- Continued with CVC words (e.g., “cup, cat, coat, bike, back”) and introduced carrier phrases such as “my cat,” “big cup,” “in back.”
- At the single-word level, final /p/ and /t/ were often correct with only light verbal cues; /k/ final was slightly less consistent but improving.
- In short phrases, he maintained some final consonants independently, though accuracy dipped compared to single words. Demonstrated a clear jump from last week in his ability to attempt end sounds in connected speech.

2. Initial /k/ in words and two-word phrases
- Targets included “key, car, cat, cookie, cow, cup” in contexts like “my car,” “big cookie.”
- Accuracy at the word level was high with minimal cueing; he often corrected himself if he started to say /t/.
- In two-word phrases, /k/ was largely maintained, suggesting generalization beyond isolated words.

3. Initial /s/ in CVC words and emerging phrases
- Practiced “sun, soup, sock, seat, sand” and phrases such as “my sock,” “see sun.”
- He produced initial /s/ more consistently in imitation, requiring moderate cues for tongue placement.
- Some spontaneous uses of /s/ in play (e.g., “snake,” “see”) were noted with reasonably clear production.

4. Early /s/ blends – imitation
- Briefly introduced /s/ blends at the word level (e.g., “spoon, stop”) using slow, segmented models.
- Client attempted blends but often omitted the /s/ or simplified the cluster (e.g., “poon” for “spoon”).
- This was framed as an exploratory task; not yet ready for higher-level practice.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue working final consonants and initial /k/ in short phrases to solidify carryover.
- Maintain focus on initial /s/ at the word and simple phrase level; revisit /s/ blends in a more structured way once single /s/ is consistently accurate.
- Parents encouraged to model short phrases with strong final consonants at home (e.g., “big cup,” “hot soup”) during daily routines.

Parent report:
Mother noted that he is putting more words together at home, often using 3–4 word phrases. She feels his “k” sound is usually there now, but she still hears dropped end sounds, especially when he talks fast.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was cheerful and talkative on arrival. He was eager to show the clinician a toy car he brought from home. Participation remained good, though he occasionally rushed through words when excited. Gentle reminders to use his “slow, careful talking” were effective.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, k) in phrases and simple sentences
- Practiced short phrases and emerging simple sentences (e.g., “I want cup,” “put it back,” “I see cat”).
- Accuracy of final /p/ and /t/ remained similar to last session: generally good with verbal reminders, more variable when speaking quickly.
- Final /k/ in phrases showed small, steady gains; he is increasingly aware when the end sound is missing but still needs prompts to correct.

2. Initial /k/ in phrases and short sentences
- Used picture description tasks with phrases like “big car,” “my cookie,” “I see a cow.”
- Performance was largely stable compared to last week: /k/ remained well-established in most contexts with minimal cueing.
- Occasional fronting to /t/ was noted in longer or less familiar phrases, but he often accepted correction and tried again.

3. Initial /s/ in CVC words and short phrases
- Targets included “sun, soup, sock, seat, sad,” with phrases such as “see sun,” “my sock.”
- Accuracy showed a slight increase; he more consistently produced a clear /s/ at the start of words with moderate cueing.
- Spontaneous /s/ in play was present but still less consistent than in structured tasks.

4. Brief probe of /s/ blends
- Rechecked /s/ blends (“spoon, star, stop”) at the imitated word level.
- Similar pattern to previous trial: frequent reduction of the blend to a single consonant, with some emerging correct attempts when words were heavily segmented.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue consolidating final consonants and /k/ in phrases; maintain current level of complexity.
- Ongoing work on initial /s/ with a focus on consistency; blends to remain a lower priority until single /s/ is more stable.
- At home, encourage “slow talking” during key routines (e.g., mealtime, bath) and reinforce clear final sounds without overcorrecting.

Parent report:

Behaviour/engagement:

Parent report:

Behaviour/engagement:
Client arrived in good spirits and transitioned smoothly. He showed strong engagement with a new board game activity and was motivated by taking turns and earning small rewards. Needed only minimal redirection to stay on task.

Parent report:
Mother reported that he is “much clearer” when talking about his favorite toys and books. She specifically noticed better /s/ in words like “sun” and “soap,” and that his cousins are asking for repetition less often.

Behaviour/engagement:
Client was enthusiastic and talkative throughout the session. He attended well to both table-top and floor-based activities and enjoyed being the “teacher” to correct the clinician’s silly errors. Very responsive to visual feedback using a mirror.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonants (p, t, k) in sentences and structured play
- Used short sentences during play (e.g., “I put it back,” “The cat is on top,” “I like soup”).
- Noticeable improvement: he maintained final /p/ and /t/ in many sentences with minimal cueing and showed better consistency with final /k/ than in previous weeks.
- When excited, some omissions still occurred, but he often attempted to fix them when prompted (“Say it with your end sound”).

2. Initial /k/ in varied sentence positions
- Practiced sentences such as “The car is fast,” “The cookie is big,” “The cow is sleeping.”
- /k/ was produced accurately in initial positions with little to no cueing.
- Accuracy remained strong even as sentence structures varied, suggesting good generalization.

3. Initial /s/ in CVC words and short sentences
- Targets included “sun, soup, soap, seat, sad,” with sentences like “The sun is hot,” “I see soap.”
- Marked improvement: he produced initial /s/ more consistently with reduced cueing and clearer airflow.
- Several spontaneous uses of /s/ in conversation were intelligible (e.g., “so big,” “see it”), showing carryover beyond drill tasks.

4. /s/ blends at the imitated word level
- Focused on /st/ and /sp/ blends (e.g., “stop, star, spoon, spot”) using slow, segmented models.
- He successfully produced some accurate blends, particularly /st/, when given clear visual and verbal cues.
- While not yet fully consistent, this represented a meaningful step up from earlier attempts.

Plan / recommendations:
- Begin to incorporate more sentence-level practice for final consonants and initial /s/ to support generalization.
- Continue structured practice of /s/ blends, starting with easier clusters (/st/) before expanding.
- Caregivers encouraged to notice and praise clear /s/ and final consonant productions in everyday conversation and to model short sentences with those sounds.

- Continued practicing /s/ blends at the imitated word level (“stop, star, spoon, spider, spill”) and trialed short phrases such as “stop it” and “big star.”
- Blends remained the most challenging area; he frequently reduced clusters, with a few correct /st/ productions when given slow, segmented models.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue therapy focusing on consolidation of final consonants and /s/ at the sentence level and gradual improvement of /s/ blends.
- Recommend ongoing home practice with simple picture cards and daily routines, emphasizing clear end sounds and the “snake sound” /s/ at the beginning of words.
- Consider future re-evaluation of goals to determine readiness for more intensive work on blends and further generalization into less structured conversation.

Goals / session focus:
1) Establish baseline for speech sound production
- Collected informal probe of consonants in isolation and simple syllables (CV, CVCV) during play-based tasks.
- Noted frequent substitutions for /k/ and /g/ (fronting to /t/ and /d/), inconsistent marking of final consonants, and reduced accuracy for /s/ and /sh/ in initial position.
- Intelligibility higher in known routines but reduced in spontaneous conversation.

2) Initial /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Practiced /k/ in isolation using visual of “back sound” and tongue depressor for awareness (no intra-oral contact).
- Child was able to approximate /k/ in isolation with maximal verbal and visual cues in about half of attempts; often reverted to /t/ when excited.
- At CV level (e.g., “koo,” “kay”), productions were mostly /too/ and /tay/ despite simultaneous models.

3) Final consonant awareness (CVC words – early stops /p, t/)
- Introduced idea of “end sound” using picture cards and tapping for CVC words (e.g., “cup,” “cat”).
- Child could sometimes imitate final /p/ with direct modeling and slowed rate; final /t/ was usually omitted or replaced with a vowel.
- Required frequent verbal reminders to “add the end sound” and benefited from segmenting the word.

4) Initial /s/ at isolation level
- Introduced “long, quiet snake sound.”
- Child attempted /s/ in isolation with variable success; often produced /d/ or a short, distorted sound.
- Tolerated mirror work and watching clinician’s mouth; needed continuous cueing for airflow.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to target /k/ in isolation and CV syllables, final consonant marking in simple CVC words, and establish a clearer /s/ in isolation.
- Encourage parent to model slow, clear productions in play (e.g., emphasizing final sounds in words like “cup,” “hat”).
- Plan to gather additional baseline on /sh/ and blends in upcoming sessions.

Session 1
Child age: 4;0

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother shared that she and daycare staff notice that others have difficulty understanding him, especially with new people.
- No recent changes in health or hearing reported.
- Parent is most concerned about his “funny” /s/ and that he leaves off sounds at the ends of words.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Transitioned to therapy room with some hesitation but separated from mother with reassurance.
- Once engaged in play-based tasks, he was cheerful and cooperative.
- Attention span was appropriate for age with occasional redirection back to the task.

Therapy goals and observations:
Goal 1: Establish accurate production of /s/ in isolation and simple syllables (imitation)
- Baseline probing revealed difficulty sustaining a clear /s/; frequent lateral airflow and occasional /t/ substitutions.
- With visual model and verbal cue to “keep your tongue behind your teeth and blow,” he produced a recognizable /s/ in isolation in about half of attempts.
- In simple CV syllables (e.g., “see,” “suh”), accuracy decreased; required frequent repetition and close visual model.

Goal 2: Explore initial /f/ production in isolation and CV syllables (imitation)
- Initial attempt at /f/ showed labiodental placement emerging but inconsistent airflow; often substituted /p/.
- With cueing to “bite your lip and blow,” he achieved accurate /f/ in isolation in several trials but was not yet consistent.
- In syllables (e.g., “fee,” “fo”), productions were mostly approximations; needed maximal verbal and gestural support.

Goal 3: Assess final consonant production at single word level
- Probed CVC words with final /p, t, m/ in play (e.g., “cup, cat, mom”).
- Frequently omitted final consonants or added a neutral vowel (“cu,” “ca-uh”).
- When cued to “keep your sound on” or given a simultaneous model, he could mark some final consonants, but accuracy was low and not yet reliable.

Goal 4: Obtain general speech/language sample
- During free play, used many 2–3 word phrases (e.g., “my car,” “want that one”).
- Intelligibility to clinician unfamiliar with him was reduced, particularly in longer utterances and with less contextual support.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to build /s/ and /f/ in isolation and simple syllables with strong visual and verbal cues.
- Begin systematic work on final consonant marking with high-frequency CVC words.
- Parent educated on using a mirror at home to practice “snake sound /s/” and “lip-bite sound /f/” for a few minutes daily in a playful way.
- Plan to introduce simple picture-based word practice for /s/ and /f/ once isolation becomes more stable.

Goal 4: Functional phrases in play
- Modeled short carrier phrases (e.g., “my ___,” “I want ___”) and encouraged imitation.
- He readily imitated many phrases; speech remained reduced in clarity but willingness to attempt longer utterances was strong.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue focusing on /s/ and /f/ in isolation and syllables, gradually reducing cueing where possible.
- Maintain work on final consonant marking with a small core set of CVC words.

- Anticipate trialing initial /s/ and /f/ at word level next session if current gains are maintained.

Parent report:
- Mother shared that she is most concerned about how hard it is for unfamiliar listeners to understand him. She reports that he is talking in short sentences at home but often leaves off the ends of words. No recent changes in health or hearing.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Client transitioned to the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from mother with encouragement. Once engaged in play, he was cheerful and cooperative. Attention to adult-directed tasks was fair; needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to speech tasks.

Goals / session focus:
1. Final consonant production in CVC words (p, t, m)
- Targeted final /p, t, m/ in simple words (e.g., pop, hat, mom) at the imitated word level. Client frequently omitted the final consonant or added a neutral vowel ("pah" for "pop"). With maximal verbal models and visual cues (tapping for the last sound, hand-to-mouth cue), he produced clearer final consonants in a small number of trials, but accuracy was inconsistent and required significant support.

2. Initial /s/ in single words
- Introduced initial /s/ in isolation and at the imitated word level (sun, soup, sock). In isolation, he approximated /s/ with a more /sh/ or /th/-like sound. At the word level, /s/ was often substituted or omitted. Required frequent cueing to keep tongue behind teeth and to use a “quiet snake sound.” Limited success with independent productions.

3. Syllable shapes (CV, CVCV)
- Observed and elicited a range of syllable shapes in play (e.g., "mama," "baba," "tata" for car sounds). CV and reduplicated CVCV forms were easier. When cued to attempt alternating CVCV (e.g., "bunny," "tiger"), he tended to reduce them to shorter forms ("bu," "tie").

4. Functional phrases for requesting
- During play, modeled simple 2–3 word phrases ("my turn," "more cars," "open please"). Client mostly used single words or jargon. He imitated short phrases in a few opportunities when given a direct model and enthusiastic reinforcement.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to target final consonants at the imitated word level with heavy visual and verbal cueing.
- Maintain focus on initial /s/ in isolation and simple words; consider adding tactile cues as tolerated.
- Encourage parents to model clear final sounds in everyday words (e.g., "up," "cup," "bed") without pressuring him to repeat.
- Next session: re-check final consonants and initial /s/; consider introducing simple /s/-blend perception activities if appropriate.

Goals / session focus:

Continued to add a slight vowel after some consonants but showed more attempts to “stop” his voice at the end of the word. Goals / session focus:

- Continued practice with final /p, t, m/ in CVC words and simple minimal pairs (e.g., "bee"/"beep," "see"/"seat"). Discrimination of minimal pairs was generally accurate with picture choices.

- Trialed final consonants within simple carrier phrases ("my cup," "big hat") in imitation. Client was able to maintain the final consonant on some words when the phrase was slowed down and segmented. - Continued to model functional 2–3 word phrases for commenting and requesting ("more bubbles," "my turn," "go fast"). Client imitated several phrases accurately. Spontaneous speech during play included frequent 2-word combinations and occasional 3-word utterances, though articulation remained reduced in clarity.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain focus on consolidating final consonants in CVC words and short carrier phrases; aim for greater consistency before increasing complexity.
- Continue work on /s/ in isolation and a small word set, prioritizing accuracy over quantity.

1. Final consonant production (CVC words/phrases)

2. Initial /k/ at word and phrase level
- Revisited core /k/ words using a picture lotto game.

3. /s/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Continued "snake sound" practice with mirror and visual cue.

- Continued practice with initial /k/ words and short carrier phrases using play-based tasks.

3. /s/ at syllable and emerging word level

2. Initial /k/ at word, carrier phrase, and emerging spontaneous level

4. Functional phrases including target sounds

Behaviour/engagement:
- Calm and cooperative; followed the transition routine without difficulty.
- Participated well in structured tasks, with good willingness to try and repeat when given feedback.

Therapy goals and observations:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words and short phrases)
- Practiced a variety of CVC words, mixing known and new vocabulary.
- Continued to show stable performance, with final consonants present in most imitated words and many short phrases.

2. Initial /k/ at word and phrase level
- Focused on /k/ in both familiar and less familiar words.

3. Initial /s/ at imitated word level

4. Short phrases and early sentences
- Modeled simple 3–4 word sentences incorporating target sounds ("I see big car," "my sock is on").

Plan/recommendations:

- Home: encourage practice of simple 3–4 word sentences using his practice words (e.g., "I see sun," "my car is red").
- Next session: re-check /s/ and /k/ consistency and monitor for any natural increases in independence or generalization.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that he is using longer sentences at home, but she still finds herself guessing based on context.
- She notices that when she reminds him to "slow down and use your sounds," his words are clearer.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Entered the room independently and appeared comfortable with the routine.
- Remained engaged in structured and play-based tasks, accepting feedback and cues without frustration.

Therapy goals and observations:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words/phrases)
- Continued mixed practice of CVC words and short phrases.
- Maintained strong accuracy with final consonants in imitated words; similar profile to recent sessions.
- In short phrases and simple sentences, final consonants were present much of the time, with some omissions during rapid speech.

2. Initial /k/ at word, phrase, and simple sentence level
- Practiced /k/ words in short carrier phrases and simple sentences ("I see a cat," "my car is big").

- Occasionally reverted to fronting in longer utterances; responded to a single reminder.

3. Initial /s/ at imitated word level and short phrases
- Practiced core /s/ initial words and introduced a few short phrases ("sun up," "sock on").
- Produced clearer /s/ in many imitated words when using visual/verbal cues; overall performance similar to last week.
- Phrases with /s/ were more challenging; he often needed multiple models.

4. Functional sentences
- Modeled short 3–4 word functional sentences ("I want more bubbles," "my car goes fast").
- He imitated several of these; target sounds were sometimes present, sometimes reduced, especially in the middle or end of the sentence.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue current goals, focusing on stability and generalization of final consonants, /k/, and /s/ into connected speech.
- Home: practice short, slow sentences with target words, using reminders to "slow down" and "finish your words."
- Next session: plan to review progress across the block and discuss next steps with caregiver.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that overall she feels he is "definitely clearer" than when he started, though she still needs to ask for repeats when he is tired or talking fast.
- She is interested in continuing to support his speech at home and at daycare.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Calm and cooperative; transitioned easily and participated in selecting activities.
- Maintained good engagement throughout session and appeared proud of his "strong sounds" when praised.

Therapy goals and observations:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words, phrases, and simple sentences)
- Reviewed a broad set of CVC words, including both familiar and less familiar vocabulary.
- Final consonants were present in most imitated words with minimal cueing; performance consistent with recent sessions.

2. Initial /k/ across word, phrase, and simple sentence levels

3. Initial /s/ at word and short phrase level
- Reviewed core /s/ initial words and practiced short phrases ("big sun," "sock on," "see soap").
- Able to produce recognizable /s/ in many imitated words when using established visual/verbal cues; performance similar to recent sessions.
- Phrases remained more challenging, with some substitutions and inconsistent accuracy.

4. Functional connected speech
- Encouraged use of 3–4 word sentences during play (e.g., "my car is blue," "I want more bubbles").
- He produced a range of short sentences spontaneously; intelligibility was generally better than at the start of the block, but still reduced in longer or faster speech.

Plan/recommendations:
- Recommend continuation of speech therapy to further support generalization of final consonants and /k/ into longer utterances and to continue developing accuracy and consistency for /s/ at the word and phrase levels.
- Home: continue daily short practice sessions focusing on CVC words, /k/ words, and a small set of /s/ words, integrating them into simple sentences. Emphasize slow rate and "strong ending" and "snake" sounds.
- Suggest sharing current targets and cueing strategies with daycare staff to promote consistency across settings.
