notes.note_text:
Parent report:
Mom shared that she and daycare staff notice that others sometimes have difficulty understanding child’s words, especially when they are excited. She reports frequent omissions of sounds in longer words and that child often leaves off the ends of words (e.g., “ca” for “cat”). No major changes since initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
Child transitioned with mild hesitation but separated from mom with reassurance. Engaged well in floor play with cars and animals. Attention was variable; needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to speech tasks, but responded to visual supports and turn-taking games.

Goals / Observations:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted final consonants in simple words (e.g., pop, map, hat, cup) at the imitated word level.
- Child frequently omitted the final consonant or reduced it to a very weak production.
- With maximal verbal cues (“keep your sound at the end”) and visual cues (pointing to picture edges), child produced clear final consonants in approximately half of opportunities.

2. Initial /k/ in syllables and single words
- Practiced /k/ in isolation and CV syllables (e.g., “kuh,” “kee,” “kah”).
- Child tended to substitute /t/ for /k/ (“tea” for “key”).
- With tongue-back cueing (“tongue tip down, back sound”) and mirror work, child could imitate /k/ in isolation inconsistently and in a few CV syllables.

3. Initial /s/ in single words
- Targeted initial /s/ at the imitated word level (sun, sock, soup, seat).
- Child often substituted /d/ or omitted the sound entirely.
- When watching clinician’s mouth and using a “snake sound” visual, child produced a few accurate /s/ in isolation; word-level accuracy remained low.

4. Syllable shape production (CV, CVCV)
- Observed syllable structures during play-based naming tasks.
- Child produced CV and CVCV (same consonant) forms reliably (e.g., “mama,” “baba”) but tended to simplify more complex forms.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue weekly therapy focusing on final consonants and initial /k/ and /s/ in simple words.
- Encourage slow, clear speech at home using short word lists (e.g., “pop, map, hat”) and praise any attempts to include the ending sound.
- Next session: further probe final consonants and determine most stimulable sounds to build initial target set.

Parent report:
Mom reports child is “trying to copy” words more at home and will sometimes repeat after her when she models slowly. She continues to notice dropped ending sounds but feels child is a bit more willing to repeat words when asked. No concerns with hearing or health this week.

Behaviour/engagement:
Child entered the room readily and appeared comfortable with clinician. Enjoyed turn-taking games and responded well to visual schedules. Needed intermittent redirection when toys became very exciting, but overall participation was improved compared to last visit.

Goals / Observations:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Practiced in play-based tasks (feeding animals, popping bubbles) at the imitated word level.
- Compared to last session, child produced final consonants more consistently when given a clear model and immediate visual cue (tapping a token for the end sound).
- Accuracy was noticeably higher with /p/ and /m/ (e.g., “map,” “pop”) and emerging with /t/ (“hat,” “cat”). Still needed moderate verbal reminders but fewer full prompts.

2. Initial /k/ in CV/CVC
- Continued with mirror and tongue-back cues. Child was able to produce /k/ in isolation more reliably today.
- Imitated several CV syllables (e.g., “kuh,” “kee”) with less direct shaping.
- Began to attempt /k/ in simple words (key, car, coat) with mixed accuracy; often approximated but there were more recognizable /k/ productions than last week.

3. Initial /s/ in single words
- Used “snake sound” visuals and auditory bombardment before imitation.
- Child produced /s/ in isolation multiple times when cued to smile and keep the tongue behind the teeth.
- At word level (sun, sock, soup), child showed emerging accuracy, still substituting or omitting in many attempts but with more frequent correct productions when carefully imitating.

4. Functional words/phrases
- During play, child spontaneously used some short phrases (e.g., “my turn,” “more please”) though speech clarity was variable.
- When prompted to repeat short functional phrases slowly, intelligibility improved somewhat.

Plan/Recommendations:
- Continue with final consonant practice at home using simple picture cards; encourage “slow and strong ending.”
- Provide mom with /k/ practice words and remind her to use the “back sound” cue rather than repeated drilling when child is tired.
- Next session: consider introducing simple phrases with final consonants for highly stimulable words if accuracy continues to increase.

Parent report:
Mom notes that child is now sometimes adding a sound at the end of a few words like “up” and “mom,” especially when she reminds them. She reports that family members have commented that child is “a bit clearer” in some situations. Still notices difficulty with “k” and “s” sounds in conversation.

Behaviour/engagement:
Child transitioned smoothly, quickly engaged with preferred toys (blocks, animals). Demonstrated good eye contact and turn-taking. Tolerated structured drill tasks well when embedded in games (e.g., block towers, sticker chart) and responded positively to specific praise.

Goals / Observations:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t, n/)
- Expanded set of final consonants to include /n/ (e.g., “sun,” “pan”).
- At the imitated word level, child produced final /p/ and /m/ with high consistency and final /t/ and /n/ with moderate consistency.
- Able to carry over accurate final consonants into short carrier phrases (e.g., “my ___,” “I see ___”) for highly practiced words with clinician modeling.

2. Initial /k/ at word level
- Continued targeting initial /k/ in single words (key, car, cat, coat, cup) at the imitated level.
- Compared to last session, there was a clear increase in correct /k/ productions, with fewer substitutions to /t/.
- Required less intensive tongue-placement shaping; visual cues and a brief reminder were often sufficient.

- Accuracy in isolation remained good with cues; at the word level, there was an increase in correct productions when child slowed down.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Parent reported that child is talking more but is still "hard to understand" for people outside the family. Noted that words like "sun," "soap," and "fish" are often unclear. No concerns with hearing or overall health this week.

Behaviour/engagement:

Goals and observations:
1. Baseline for initial /s/ at word level (imitation)
- Probed initial /s/ in single words (e.g., sun, sock, soup, see, sit) primarily in imitation. Productions were highly inconsistent; frequent substitutions included /d/ and /z/ (e.g., "dun" for sun, "zock" for sock). Child benefited from visual cue to show “smile teeth” and gentle verbal reminders to keep the tongue behind the teeth. Accuracy was low overall, but child attempted most items when supported.

2. Baseline for initial /f/ at word level (imitation)
- Assessed initial /f/ in words (e.g., fish, fan, five, foot). Child tended to stop /f/ to /p/ ("pish" for fish) or used /h/ ("hish"). Brief instruction on “bite your lip and blow” helped the child approximate /f/ in isolation with significant effort and modeling. Limited carryover into words; productions remained mostly inaccurate without maximal cues.

3. Baseline for /s/ blends (imitation in play)
- Introduced simple /s/ blends at the imitated word level in play (e.g., spill, stop, spin). Child often omitted the /s/ ("pill," "top," "pin"). Required direct models and simultaneous production with the clinician. Very few clear productions; this target is emerging and will remain at the imitated word level.

4. Overall speech sound profile
- During free play and conversation, child used many single words and short phrases, but overall intelligibility was reduced, especially with unfamiliar listeners. Occasional final consonants were omitted (e.g., "ca" for cat), though not consistently. Parent was able to understand most of child’s speech with contextual support.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to build rapport and gather additional baseline data for /s/, /f/, and /s/ blends.
- Begin structured practice of initial /s/ and /f/ at the imitated word level with strong visual and verbal cues.
- Encourage parent to model clear /s/ and /f/ words in daily routines (e.g., "sun," "sock," "fish," "food") without asking child to repeat yet; focus on exposure.
- Monitor tolerance for more structured practice and consider introducing simple CV syllables if needed.

In carrier phrases ("I see sun," "my soap"), accuracy was fair but variable; some phrases were clear, while others showed reduced /s/ or substitution. Spontaneous use of /s/ in familiar words occurred occasionally during play but was not yet consistent.

2. Initial /f/ in words and short phrases (imitation)
- Continued work on initial /f/ at the word level (fish, four, fan, food). Accuracy was similar to previous session, with several clear productions when child attended to lip placement. Occasional /p/ substitutions persisted. Modeled short phrases ("four fish," "fun food") remained at the imitated level; child needed direct models and did not yet use these spontaneously.

3. /s/ blends at imitated word level
- Practiced /s/ blends (spin, stop, slide, spill, spot) in a board game. Child continued to omit /s/ in many attempts ("pin," "top"), though a few productions included a brief /s/ when strongly cued. Performance was comparable to last week; no notable jump in accuracy, but the child tolerated repeated practice and remained engaged.

4. Final consonants (brief practice)
- Revisited final /t/ and /p/ in imitation (cat, hat, cup, up). Child could mark final consonants with cueing but did not yet carry this over into spontaneous speech. This remains a lower priority target.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue practicing /s/ and /f/ at the word and carrier phrase level, focusing on maintaining gains and increasing consistency.
- Keep /s/ blends at the imitated word level; focus on awareness and willingness to attempt the full cluster.
- Parent encouraged to continue home practice with short, fun games (e.g., pointing to pictures and saying "see sun," "fun fish"), keeping practice brief and positive.
- Monitor for readiness to expand phrase-level work when productions become more reliable.

Parent report:
- Mother reported that she understands him most of the time but unfamiliar listeners still have difficulty.
- No major changes since the evaluation; family is motivated to work on “clear sounds.”

Behaviour/engagement:
- 4-year-old boy, transitioned into the therapy room with brief hesitation but separated from caregiver without distress.
- Engaged well in play-based tasks (cars, animal toys); followed simple directions and participated with encouragement.
- Attention was fair; needed occasional redirection from self-directed play back to sound practice.

Goals / therapy focus:
1) Establish /k/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Baseline probing revealed fronting of /k/ to /t/ in most positions (e.g., “tar” for “car”).
- With maximal verbal cueing ("tongue back sound") and use of a tongue depressor for awareness, he was able to approximate /k/ in isolation in a few trials, but accuracy was inconsistent.
- CV syllables ("ku, ka, ko") were attempted with model + visual cue; most productions were closer to /t/.

2) Establish /s/ in isolation
- Tended to produce /s/ as /d/ or a lateralized sound.
- With mirror and snake imagery ("quiet snake sound"), he achieved a few clear /s/ productions in isolation when given direct modeling and verbal shaping cues.
- No reliable carryover to syllables yet.

3) Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Frequently substituted /p/ for /f/ in conversation.
- With model and placement cue ("bite your lip, blow"), he produced /f/ correctly in isolation in several trials, but needed frequent reminders.
- CV syllables ("foo, fee, fah") were attempted; many productions had a stop onset (/p/) before or instead of /f/.

4) Baseline sampling at word level
- Collected informal speech sample during play; noted patterns of fronting (/k, g/ to /t, d/), stopping of /f, s/, and occasional cluster reduction for /s/-blends.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue weekly sessions targeting /k/, /s/, and /f/ at isolation and simple syllable levels.
- Teach caregiver to model /f/ at home in front of a mirror (e.g., "fish, five, fun") focusing on lip placement, keeping it fun and brief.
- Next session: further establish placement for /k/ and /s/, consider using more tactile and visual supports and introduce high-interest games to pair with sound practice.

Goals / therapy focus:
1) /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Marked breakthrough with /k/ in isolation using mirror and “cough” trick; produced a clear /k/ repeatedly when cued to “cough then freeze the back sound.”
- Able to imitate CV syllables ("ku, ki, ka") with moderate cues; about half were clearly backed /k/ rather than /t/.
- Began to discriminate between /k/ vs /t/ when listening to minimal pairs in a picture game.

2) /f/ in isolation and initial CV syllables
- Improved consistency with /f/ in isolation when reminded to “bite lip and blow”; multiple accurate productions in a row were observed.
- In CV syllables ("foo, fee, fi"), he produced clearer /f/ onset in many attempts with verbal and visual cueing.
- Less frequent /p/ substitutions compared to baseline during structured tasks, though still present.

3) /s/ in isolation and attempt at simple syllables
- Continued work on “quiet snake” sound with mirror; more frequent accurate hissing /s/ in isolation with clinician model.
- Trialed CV syllables ("see, soo"); he tended to add a /t/ before /s/ (e.g., "tsee"). With slowed rate and modeling, a few closer approximations were achieved.

4) Auditory discrimination for target sounds
- Played a listening game to identify whether clinician said “tea” or “key”; he was often able to point to the correct picture when given time.
- This activity seemed to help his awareness of the difference between /k/ and /t/.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen /k/ and /f/ in syllables; begin probing for /k/ in simple words next session if consistency remains.
- Encourage brief daily practice of /f/ words at home (e.g., fish, food, fun) with visual cue (caregiver showing lip position).
- Continue to build /s/ in isolation; introduce more play-based listening tasks for /s/ vs other sounds.

Goals / session focus:

- Explored /s/ as a "quiet snake sound." Child could approximate a prolonged airflow sound but often added a /t/ or /d/ onset. In isolation, a few clear /s/ productions were observed with direct imitation and modeling of smile and airflow. At this time, child was not ready to move to syllables.

- Used a small set of functional words ("up, pop, more, me") to observe natural productions. Child often reduced consonant clusters and omitted final sounds. Occasional clearer productions occurred with imitation but were not consistent.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build awareness of final sounds and back sound /k/ at isolation and simple syllable levels. Maintain focus at imitation level with heavy cueing next session.

Goals / session focus:
1) Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Established production of /f/ in isolation using mirror, airflow cues ("bite lip, blow"), and visual models. Able to imitate /f/ correctly in isolation in approximately half of opportunities with maximal verbal and visual cueing.
- At CV level ("foo, fi, fee, fa"), accuracy was low; he often substituted /p/ or omitted the sound entirely. Required hand-over-hand support for airflow and close imitation of SLP's model.

2) Final consonant production (bilabials /p, m/ in CVC words)
- Targeted simple CVC words in play (e.g., "map, mop, mom, pop"). Child frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous attempts (e.g., "ma" for "map").
- With immediate imitation and verbal cueing ("say the end sound"), he could add a final /p/ or /m/ in some trials, but productions were inconsistent.

3) Initial /s/ at single word level (emerging)
- Probed initial /s/ in a few high-interest words ("sun, sock, soap").
- Child produced distorted or substituted sounds (often /d/ or a lateralized variant). Required maximal modeling; accurate productions were rare and not yet stable.

4) Syllable shape inventory (CV and CVCV)
- Observed spontaneous use of CV ("ma, no, go") and CVCV ("mama, dada") structures during play.
- Accuracy of consonants within these shapes was variable, with frequent omissions or substitutions, but syllable rhythm was generally present.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to establish consistent /f/ production in isolation and CV syllables next session before moving to words.
- Maintain focus on final consonants /p, m/ in simple CVC words with strong visual and verbal cues.
- Provide parent with simple home practice: 3–4 target /f/ sounds in the mirror (no pressure, just playfully copying the "blowing" sound), and emphasize final sounds in everyday words (e.g., "up, pop") by slightly exaggerating them.

- Practiced /s/ in isolation with mirror support. Child produced a clear /s/ in some attempts, but often substituted /t/ or a lateralized sound. In CV syllables (e.g., “see, soo”), accuracy was low, with frequent stopping. Required maximal verbal cues to “keep tongue behind teeth and blow.”

3. Final consonant production (awareness and simple CVC words)
- In play-based tasks, child frequently omitted final consonants (e.g., “ca” for “cat,” “do” for “dog”). With direct imitation and visual cueing (pointing to the end of a picture), child occasionally added final sounds, but this was inconsistent. Accuracy remained low overall, indicating this remains an emerging skill.

4. Functional communication in play
- Child used mainly 2–3 word phrases (e.g., “my turn,” “more bubbles”) spontaneously. Speech was often reduced in clarity due to sound errors, but intent was generally understandable in context. Accepted models for slightly longer phrases (e.g., “more bubbles please”) and occasionally imitated them.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue to target initial /f/ and /s/ at the isolation and simple syllable levels with heavy visual/verbal cueing.
- Continue to build awareness of final consonants in high-interest CVC words.
- Encourage parent to model clear /f/ and /s/ sounds during daily routines (e.g., “fish,” “feet,” “soap”) without pressure for the child to repeat.
- Plan to gather additional baseline data on /s/ blends in the next session.
